title: Multi-task Self-Supervised Visual Learning
abstract: We investigate methods for combining multiple selfsupervised tasks—i.e., supervised tasks where data can be collected without manual labeling—in order to train a single visual representation. First, we provide an apples-toapples comparison of four different self-supervised tasks using the very deep ResNet-101 architecture. We then combine tasks to jointly train a network. We also explore lasso regularization to encourage the network to factorize the information in its representation, and methods for “harmonizing” network inputs in order to learn a more unified representation. We evaluate all methods on ImageNet classification, PASCAL VOC detection, and NYU depth prediction. Our results show that deeper networks work better, and that combining tasks—even via a na¨ýve multihead architecture—always improves performance. Our best joint network nearly matches the PASCAL performance of a model pre-trained on ImageNet classification, and matches the ImageNet network on NYU depth prediction.
venue: IEEE International Conference on Computer Vision

tldr.text: The results show that deeper networks work better, and that combining tasks—even via a na¨ýve multihead architecture—always improves performance.
